captions.text:
In cosmology we believe that the universe
started off in a big bang 13.7 billion years

ago. All alternatives have been pretty much
ruled out. Steady state theories, other alternatives

have been ruled out. However, how will the
universe end? We have several possibilities.

One possibility is a big crunch when the universe
squashes together in a gigantic ball of flame

and maybe bangs once again. Another possibility
is the big freeze, that the universe expands

and just keeps on going and we're all going
to freeze to death and we're all going to

die when the universe reaches near absolute
zero. Then there is something called the big

rip where the universe goes into an exponential
expansion and expands so rapidly that the

distant galaxies can no longer be seen because
they travel faster than the speed of light,

that even the distant galaxies break the light
barrier, and that's called the big rip, meaning

that the night sky will be totally black except
for some of the nearby stars.

Which of the three alternatives is the fate
of the universe? Well, the short answer is

we don't know. However, what we do know is
that the universe is undergoing an exponential

runaway expansion. The universe at the present
time is careening out of control. Every astronomy

textbook says that there was a big bang. The
universe is expanding, but it's slowing down.

It also says that the universe is mainly made
out of atoms. Every textbook says that. The

universe is made out of atoms. The universe
is expanding, but slowing down. Both are wrong.

We have to rewrite every single high school
textbook on the planet earth. The universe
is not mainly made out of atoms.

Four percent of the universe is made out of
atoms, just four percent. 23% is made out

of dark matter. 73%, which makes up most of
the universe, is dark energy, and unfortunately,

we are clueless as to what dark energy is
and what dark matter is. In fact, if you ever

find out what dark energy and dark matter
is, be sure to tell me first.

Now why is that important? Because the amount
of matter and energy in the universe determines

the rate of expansion. We now know there is
a lot more dark energy than we previously

thought. Therefore, the universe is undergoing
an inflationary exponential expansion. It

is in a runaway mode, but here is the catch:
we don't know how long that runaway mode is

going to last. Some people say that it's temporary.
We're in this huge expansion right now, exponential

expansion, but it's going to reverse itself.
Instead of a red shift, we'll have a blue

shift as the universe collapses. At the present
time we simply don't know. Why don't we know?

Because we don't know what dark energy is.
In fact, if you were to try to write down

a theory of dark energy, your number would
not correspond to the data by a mismatch of

10 to the 120. That is the largest mismatch
in the history of science. There is no mismatch

bigger than 10 to the 120. So this is a mystery.
Until we solve the mystery of dark energy,
we do not know the ultimate fate of the universe.

My personal thoughts are that perhaps we will
continue with this exponential expansion and

perhaps go into a big rip mode and at that
point all intelligent life in the universe

will die. All the tears and all the struggles
and all the heartbreak of humanity since we

rose from the swamp, it's all for nothing.
Why should you bother to wake up tomorrow

knowing that we're all going to die billions
and billions of years from now when the universe

turns to absolute zero, when the stars blink
out, when we have nothing but neutron stars

and black holes? What does it all mean anyway,
if we're all going to die in a big rip?

Well, my personal attitude is that when the
universe is about to die, why not leave the

universe? Trillions of years from now, we
will have the ability to bend space and time

into a pretzel. We'll be able to tie space
into knots. We'll be what is called a type

three, maybe a type four civilization, a galactic
civilization with the capability of harnessing

galactic power. At that point, when the universe
becomes so cold that all life is freezing

to death, I say let us escape the universe,
go into hyperspace and go to another universe.

title: Michio Kaku: What's the Fate of the Universe? It's in the Dark Matter

comments.author: AteXileR

comments.text:
Very interesting world view.

If we take in account that:

"Dark matter is a hypothetical kind of matter that cannot be seen with telescopes but accounts for most of the matter in the universe. The existence and properties of dark matter are inferred from its gravitational effects on visible matter, radiation, and the large-scale structure of the universe."

"In physical cosmology and astronomy, dark energy is an unknown form of energy which is thought by some physicists to permeate all of space, tending to accelerate the expansion of the universe."
Source: Wikipedia.org

We can assume that Newtonian theory developed further so in modern times vacuum, emptiness and maybe spirit itself can be seen as dark matter or energy.
But somehow its logical consequence of materialistic approach to absolute space existence by Newton. And sure, we must fill it with something...

Link to related post: https://plus.google.com/106669019707554339538/posts/8LmeQP31chR

comments.text:
Very interesting video and I feel I'm bound to mention that I love this 
guy's work and his personality, but what he said about the ultimate end was 
pure nonsense. I mean when he concluded that because humanity will 
inevitably perish all of it's tears and heartbreak are for nothing. This is 
a foolish statement, I see no reason why the fact that we will not last 
forever would rob our existence of meaning? After all, each individual 
human will die some day and we do not say our life is for nothing, or at 
least I think that way. The human race, just like a single human, will live 
it's life and then supposedly die - but it will have existed! With all of 
his good sides and bad sides! If anything mortality should give our life 
even more meaning, than less.

By the way, I do like the idea of escaping into another universe, but I do 
not think humanity will last forever, even if we start jumping from 
universe to universe.﻿

comments.author: Niclas Back

comments.text:
And, for the record, there is no doubt that dark matter exists; it can be 
clearly and more-or-less directly observed through the effect of 
gravitational lensing on distant galaxies, among many other points of 
evidence. Dark energy is a bit more tricky, as it likely involves phenomena 
which we cannot yet understand; that said, it's existence (like that of 
gravity, which is also still not particularly well understood, even after 
centuries of study) is in serious doubt at all. The only other possible 
explanation for the observations of an accelerating, expanding universe is 
that we are just about bang in the middle of a huge intergalactic void, 
that also (coincidentally) happens to be pulling all of the other 
observable galaxies away from us at almost exactly the same speed. Needless 
to say, the odds of this being the case are, quite literally, astronomical.
comments.author: Tyler Brown

comments.text:
Scientists are nothing at all like the clergy; for one thing, a scientist 
has absolutely no problem whatsoever stating "I don't know." Science is a 
process of discovery, and the unknown is what drives us.

Religion, in stark contrast, pretends to already possess all of the 
answers, and then violently objects whenever its concocted fairy tales are 
contradicted by actual facts.

"Dark energy" is simply the name scientists gave to the force that counters 
gravity. We have evidence that something acting as a counter to that, but 
we don't know what is it, where it comes from or how it acts. basically 
it's "dark" to us. It exists, we just don't know basically anything of it. 
Like watching a plane trail from earth without being able to touch it and 
trying to discern where it goes, what colour is it, how many fuel it has 
on, how many passengers, and what are their motivations. Maybe someday, if 
a lot of effort is put into it, we can figure it out, otherwise we can just 
speculate with our current knowledge of thermodynamics.

comments.text:
To the contrary Dr. Kaku...
If: 
X=∅
Y=∅
X=Y
Then:
X=Y
XY=Y²
XY-Y²=Y²-Y²
(X+Y)(Y-Y)=Y(Y-Y)
X+Y=Y
2Y=1Y
2=1
Ergo, if we as humans are to solve this physics conundrum, there needs to 
bring rise to a whole new integer system without any fallacies like this 
one. Don't think about it too hard, trust me, it works.

﻿

comments.text:
So he's still subscribing to the we have to be the center of the universe 
idea then?? I thought we had moved on from there centuries ago. You don't 
need blue shift to have universal collapse. If a super black hole is out of 
our sight the objects (galaxies) would be moving faster towards it. Objects 
further away moving slower would see that as red shift and objects further 
away from that moving slower would also show red shift. Think of water 
going down a bathtub drain. You would only see blue shift in a collapsing 
universe from a stationary point inside the super black hole. Ok, so how do 
we show expansion instead of collapse? measure the lateral distance of two 
galaxies over time from one another and see if they spread wider apart 
(expansion), of pull closer together ( contraction towards a point). the 
speed they are moving away from us is irrelevant. If we are collapsing into 
a super black hole then dark matter is no longer needed to explain outer 
galaxy acceleration, simple mundane physical laws explain everything fine.﻿
comments.author: Crylywn Whatsittoya

comments.text:
I believe that dark matter and dark energy are the building blocks to the 
universe, because they are absolutely nothing at all. Darkness is the key 
to light (energy) and light is the key to darkness. Without darkness there 
could be no light visa versa. When I was younger and learned about dark 
energy, I couldn't wrap my head around it, but I looked across the room at 
a bottle of hand sanitizer when I noticed all of those tiny bubbles inside 
the clear gel. Those same bubbles were an outcome of an event or action. 
They could have come from the shaking in shipping, maybe from the gel being 
deposited into the bottle, or maybe even me shaking it. Whatever it was, it 
was there and was now in existence. It didn't change the state of the gel 
or make it deplete any faster; it was just pointless scars of an old 
pointless action. They float in the middle of something else being held 
together by the gel while all was bound inside of that bottle. believe the 
same principles apply to dark matter and dark energy along with the rest of 
the universe. In a universe filled with absolutely nothing, we are the the 
little bit of something. Maybe it's because two universes clashed at one 
point, or maybe we are the universe that is "just this way" in the endless 
amounts of universes in the infinite playground of space. Only time will 
tell, i guess. ﻿

comments.author: luckygozer

comments.text:
There's too many unknown variables to answer that question with any degree 
of accuracy. No one knows if the universe is finite or infinite. Infinity 
itself is sort of an abstract. Then there's the shape of the universe, 
which is currently considered to be flat, but can potentially be something 
altogether different with no perceivable "end". So, what you're left with 
are flights of fancy. If the universe is literally all there is, I imagine 
the end would be darkness that you could either not pass into because it's 
nonexistence, or you become "nothing" as you cross this hypothetical 
threshold that separates existence from nonexistence.

comments.text:
Hmm, a lot of assumptions! If we only know something about the 4% of the 
universe, seems to me we know VERY little, and the probability of these 
theories being wrong are high. I watched his "theory of everything" video 
as well...many assumptions!  Another theory not mentioned is that the 
universe is an organism that is growing (exponentially?). Could we call 
this universe or multiverse God, and we are to God what atoms are to us? 
Isomorphism is a wonderful thing and it would bridge the gap between 
theology and science. It might also change the way we view our natural 
world and start respecting it as opposed to destroying it.  Selfish cells 
(cancer) kill the host and themselves in the end.

In his "ToE" video, he states that physics has created all the "wonderful" 
things he has pointed out, but the same physics is also responsible for the 
greatest separation between humanity and the natural world (creating some 
the greatest disasters and violence). It has created a humanity that sees 
nature as something to manipulate and control. Another assumption he makes 
is that physics will continue on it's exponential curve, but all the 
discoveries of the past relied on exponential growth and extraction of 
liquid fuels.  We are past peak oil so we are in a conundrum now.  Those 
who put their faith in science and technology (yes that's right "faith") 
assume that science and technology will solve this predicament. Those who 
condemn a belief in God for a belief in science don't realize they have 
merely exchanged messiahs (a person for technology).

 He makes the prediction that we will have the power of the gods by the 
year 2100. Will we even make it to that year in light of how we are 
destroying our planet? He seems to have benefited greatly from the system 
that's in place. This may explain his perspective and focus on all the 
benefits of science,while ignoring the negatives.﻿
